prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The friend took it as an insult and ended the conversation.

The author mentions that the friend has been making hurtful comments for two years, asking things that insult the author's appearance and dating life. Now, the key here is whether the author's response was an appropriate way to address the situation. The author's intention was to be honest, but the friend's reaction was negative. The mutual friends are now side with the friend, saying the author is privileged and a bad friend. 

I should consider if the author's statement was a valid critique or an attack. The author is pointing out a fact that could be a barrier to finding a partner, but doing so might come off as judgmental. Even if the statement is true, the delivery and context matter. The author was responding to years of insults, which might have made the situation more charged.

Also, the friend's personal situation is complex, with multiple children and no child support. The author's comment might be seen as blaming her for her circumstances, which could be hurtful. Even if the author's intention was to help, the way it was phrased could be perceived as attacking the friend's choices or lifestyle, which isn't constructive.

Moreover, the author mentions their own challenges and hard work, but the friend's friends are telling her she's being unkind. It's possible that the author overstepped by making a personal comment about her friend's personal life, even if it's true. The friend might have felt criticized for her life choices, which can be sensitive.

On the other hand, the author was defending themselves against constant insults and trying to set a boundary. But maybe there was a better way to address the issue without pointing out the friend's situation in a way that could be seen as judgmental. Perhaps a more empathetic approach would have been better, even if the author was tired of the insults.

In summary, while the author had a hard time with the friend's comments, their response might have been too direct and could have been perceived as an attack on the friend's personal life, which is a sensitive area.
